showcase_cdn_example_1.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_cdn_example_1.relevance: This will analyze your CDN logs....
showcase_cdn_example_1.description: Analyze the Top Browsers for your CDN.
showcase_cdn_example_1.name: CDN - User Behavior - Top Browsers
showcase_cdn_example_1.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdn_connections | sort - _time | fields _time http_user_agent | rename http_user_agent AS useragent | eval os = case(match(useragent,"Windows .. 5.1"),"Windows XP",match(useragent,"droid"),"Android",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.1"),"Windows 7",match(useragent,"Win98"),"Windows 98",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.3"),"Windows Server 2012",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.2"),"Windows 8",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.0"),"Windows Server 2008",match(useragent,"Windows Phone 8.1"),"Windows Mobile 8",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.10"),"OSX 10.10",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_9"),"OSX 10.9",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.6"),"OSX 10.6",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.5"),"OSX 10.5",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_8"),"OSX 10.8",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_7"),"OSX 10.7",match(useragent,"Apple TV"),"IOS",match(useragent,"iPad"),"IOS",match(useragent,"iPhone"),"IOS",match(useragent,"linux|Linux"),"Linux") | eval browser = case(match(useragent,"MSIE 10.0"),"IE 10.0",match(useragent,"MSIE 7.0"),"IE 7.0",match(useragent,"Chrome"),"Chrome",match(useragent,"Safari/"),"Safari",match(useragent,"Firefox"),"Firefox",match(useragent,"MSIE 9.0"),"IE 9.0",match(useragent,"ANVSDK ios"),"Anvato Player",match(useragent,"UCBrowser"),"UC Browser",match(useragent,"Opera"),"Opera",match(useragent,"Gecko Galeon"),"Gecko",match(useragent,"Netscape6"),"Netscape") | eval arch = case(match(useragent,"droid"),"android",match(useragent,"iPad"),"ipad",match(useragent,"iPod"),"ipod",match(useragent,"Apple TV"),"Apple TV",match(useragent,"iPhone"),"iphone",match(os,"Windows"),"x86_64",match(useragent,"Intel|x86_64"),"x86_64") | fillnull value="UNKNOWN" os arch browser | stats count by browser | sort - count

visualizations.title: Top Browsers over the Latest Time Period
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdn_connections | sort - _time | fields _time http_user_agent | rename http_user_agent AS useragent | eval os = case(match(useragent,"Windows .. 5.1"),"Windows XP",match(useragent,"droid"),"Android",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.1"),"Windows 7",match(useragent,"Win98"),"Windows 98",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.3"),"Windows Server 2012",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.2"),"Windows 8",match(useragent,"Windows NT 6.0"),"Windows Server 2008",match(useragent,"Windows Phone 8.1"),"Windows Mobile 8",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.10"),"OSX 10.10",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_9"),"OSX 10.9",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.6"),"OSX 10.6",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10.5"),"OSX 10.5",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_8"),"OSX 10.8",match(useragent,"Mac OS X 10_7"),"OSX 10.7",match(useragent,"Apple TV"),"IOS",match(useragent,"iPad"),"IOS",match(useragent,"iPhone"),"IOS",match(useragent,"linux|Linux"),"Linux") | eval browser = case(match(useragent,"MSIE 10.0"),"IE 10.0",match(useragent,"MSIE 7.0"),"IE 7.0",match(useragent,"Chrome"),"Chrome",match(useragent,"Safari/"),"Safari",match(useragent,"Firefox"),"Firefox",match(useragent,"MSIE 9.0"),"IE 9.0",match(useragent,"ANVSDK ios"),"Anvato Player",match(useragent,"UCBrowser"),"UC Browser",match(useragent,"Opera"),"Opera",match(useragent,"Gecko Galeon"),"Gecko",match(useragent,"Netscape6"),"Netscape") | eval arch = case(match(useragent,"droid"),"android",match(useragent,"iPad"),"ipad",match(useragent,"iPod"),"ipod",match(useragent,"Apple TV"),"Apple TV",match(useragent,"iPhone"),"iphone",match(os,"Windows"),"x86_64",match(useragent,"Intel|x86_64"),"x86_64") | fillnull value="UNKNOWN" os arch browser | stats count by browser | sort - count

showcase_physical_search0001.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges, Error Codes, and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0001.operationalize: This search allows us to "monitor" a specific badge as it is used around monitored facilities. This could be used for a variety of reasons such as: Activity Logging, Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, and HR Related Requests.
showcase_physical_search0001.relevance: This search takes data logged from RFID / Proxmity badge readers, enriches it with facilties and logging information, and then shows activity for a designated badge.
showcase_physical_search0001.description: Track a badge on it's journey through a designated time period.
showcase_physical_search0001.name: Security Auditing - Badge Monitoring
showcase_physical_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId OUTPUTNEW firstName lastName emailAddress employeeId note officeId | search employeeId="25020002" | fields - badgereaderId,envAlarm,errorCode,powerStatus | eval fullName = firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId employeeId fullName officeId description status note | rename badgeId AS "Badge ID #" employeeId AS "Employee Number" fullName AS "Employee Name" officeId AS "Home Office" description AS "Card Reader Location" status AS "Read Status" note AS "Additional Notes.."

visualizations.title: User Tracking by Security
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId OUTPUTNEW firstName lastName emailAddress employeeId note officeId | search employeeId="25020002" | fields - badgereaderId,envAlarm,errorCode,powerStatus | eval fullName = firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId employeeId fullName officeId description status note | rename badgeId AS "Badge ID #" employeeId AS "Employee Number" fullName AS "Employee Name" officeId AS "Home Office" description AS "Card Reader Location" status AS "Read Status" note AS "Additional Notes.."

showcase_physical_search0002.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0002.operationalize: Auditing of Physical Access is a requirement for many regulatory bodies and industrial certifications. Being able to associate ingress and egress traffic for designated rooms and zones, to badges, in near real-time expedites compliance and security.
showcase_physical_search0002.relevance: This examples searches RFID / Proximity logs for access to certain facilties and rooms. Reporting from this can be used for Security, Compliance, or Customer Reporting Requirements.
showcase_physical_search0002.description: Audit and Report on Room Access in a secure facility based on badge readers.
showcase_physical_search0002.name: Security Auditing - Secure Facilties Access
showcase_physical_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | search description="LV-DC-2-DC-003-*" | stats count list(description) AS Room list(status) AS Status list(badgeId) AS BadgeID list(employeeId) AS userId by _time | eval Personnel=if(match(userId,"-"),"Customer Card","Splunk Datacenter Staff") | eval Direction=case(match(Room,"-in"),"Ingress",match(Room,"-out"),"Egress") | eval Room=case(match(Room,"LV-DC-2-DC-003-"),"Secure Room - 3") | fields _time Room Personnel Direction | rename _time AS "Time" | convert ctime(Time)

images.name: Wire_Transfer_Fraud_NewAccount.png
images.label: Table Showing Access In and Out of Secure Room 3 of this facility.

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Secure Facilities
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | search description="LV-DC-2-DC-003-*" | stats count list(description) AS Room list(status) AS Status list(badgeId) AS BadgeID list(employeeId) AS userId by _time | eval Personnel=if(match(userId,"-"),"Customer Card","Splunk Datacenter Staff") | eval Direction=case(match(Room,"-in"),"Ingress",match(Room,"-out"),"Egress") | eval Room=case(match(Room,"LV-DC-2-DC-003-"),"Secure Room - 3") | fields _time Room Personnel Direction | rename _time AS "Time" | convert ctime(Time)

showcase_physical_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0003.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the User-to-Badges and a Reader to Card locations.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search.
showcase_physical_search0003.operationalize:
Security in facilities, especially Data Centers, is restricted and not only is there a need to control access but we also need to know who is accessing the facilities.

This example looks at where a badge has a high number of failures with an ACCESS-DENIED error. This could be indicative of a malicious user, or an employee with a badge problem. All of these should be immmediately actionable by facilities / security.
showcase_physical_search0003.relevance: In this example we look at how monitor abnormally high failures against a badge reader, or readers, over a time period. This can be indicative of a physical issue with a badge, or a security relevant situation where perhaps physical security is required.
showcase_physical_search0003.description: Let's find where access to badge readers has an abnormally high count within a 5 minute period.
showcase_physical_search0003.name: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
showcase_physical_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

images.name: Wire_Transfer_Fraud_NewAccount.png
images.label: A particular badge having a bad day.

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Abnormal Failures
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description active | lookup physical_card_user_mapping cardId AS badgeId | eval fullName=firstName+" "+lastName | fields _time badgeId description fullName status | search status="ACCESS-DENIED" OR status="READ-SUCCESS" | streamstats count reset_on_change=true window=2 by description | search (count > 1) AND status="ACCESS-DENIED" | bin span=5m _time | stats count list(badgeId) AS Badge list(description) AS Location list(fullName) as Name by _time | where count > 1 | rename _time AS Time | convert ctime(Time) | table Time Location Badge Name

showcase_physical_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_physical_search0004.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the Reader to Card locations and Error Codes. Matching the hardware codes to the environmental codes in the lookup is trivial, these are well documented by most hardware manufacturers.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search over your desired time range.
showcase_physical_search0004.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0004.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system.
showcase_physical_search0004.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms.
showcase_physical_search0004.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Check
showcase_physical_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | fields _time badgereaderId description envAlarm errorCode powerStatus status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER"

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Environmental Check
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUTNEW status | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | fields _time badgereaderId description envAlarm errorCode powerStatus status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER"

showcase_physical_search0005.howToImplement:
This search relies on a RFID / Proximity badge reader system logs and lookup tables that provide further enrichment around the Reader to Card locations and Error Codes. Matching the hardware codes to the environmental codes in the lookup is trivial, these are well documented by most hardware manufacturers.

With this data available, you can substitute in sourcetype and lookup tables to use this search over your desired time range.
showcase_physical_search0005.operationalize: Being able to monitor badge readers and correlate environmental factors to specific events is what data analytics is all about. Being able to identify a power outage in a hallway and resolve this before a customer has problems is good.
showcase_physical_search0005.relevance: In this example we show a simple search that looks at environmental alerts coming out of our badge reader system. We then perform from analytics on the data to determine an event duration and then format these in a way that can be presented.
showcase_physical_search0005.description: Most modern badger readers support various environmental triggers such as fire alarms, electricity failures, and backup battery failovers. This example shows how to search our RFID / Promixity badge system events for triggered environmental alarms and generate a nicely formated and human readable report that can be used for Compliance, Regulatory Reporting, Root Cause Analysis, etc.
showcase_physical_search0005.name: Security Auditing - Environmental Reporting
showcase_physical_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUT status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER" | sort _time | streamstats window=0 current=false latest(_time) AS previousEventTime latest(status) AS previousStatus BY description | eval duration = _time - previousEventTime | rename status AS currentStatus | fillnull value=0 duration | eval envAlarm=case(match(envAlarm,"FIRE"),"Fire Alarm Detected in Zone",match(envAlarm,"POWER"),"Power Event Detected in Zone") | fields _time description currentStatus duration envAlarm | rename description AS "Reader Location" currentStatus AS "Lock Status" envAlarm AS "Alarm" | convert ctime(previousEventTime) | where duration > 0 | rename duration AS "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" _time AS "Time Cleared" | convert ctime("Time Cleared") | table Alarm "Reader Location" "Lock Status" "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" "Time Cleared"

images.name: Wire_Transfer_Fraud_NewAccount.png
images.label: Power and fire issues all in one day?

visualizations.title: Security Auditing - Environmental Reporting
visualizations.search: | inputlookup physical_card_logs | lookup physical_card_mapping readerID AS badgereaderId OUTPUTNEW description | lookup physical_card_error_codes errorCode OUTPUT status | search envAlarm="FIRE" OR envAlarm="POWER" | sort _time | streamstats window=0 current=false latest(_time) AS previousEventTime latest(status) AS previousStatus BY description | eval duration = _time - previousEventTime | rename status AS currentStatus | fillnull value=0 duration | eval envAlarm=case(match(envAlarm,"FIRE"),"Fire Alarm Detected in Zone",match(envAlarm,"POWER"),"Power Event Detected in Zone") | fields _time description currentStatus duration envAlarm | rename description AS "Reader Location" currentStatus AS "Lock Status" envAlarm AS "Alarm" | convert ctime(previousEventTime) | where duration > 0 | rename duration AS "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" _time AS "Time Cleared" | convert ctime("Time Cleared") | table Alarm "Reader Location" "Lock Status" "Duration of Alarm (seconds)" "Time Cleared"

showcase_subscriber_search0001.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0001.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_subscriber_search0001.relevance: This looks at top sourcetypes in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_subscriber_search0001.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_subscriber_search0001.name: General Call Disposition Metrics
showcase_subscriber_search0001.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

visualizations.title: General Call Disposition Metrics
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

showcase_subscriber_search0002.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0002.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_subscriber_search0002.relevance: This looks at top sourcetypes in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_subscriber_search0002.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_subscriber_search0002.name: Failed Call Metrics - Simple
showcase_subscriber_search0002.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="FAILED" OR disposition="CONGESTED" | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - Simple
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="FAILED" OR disposition="CONGESTED" | stats count values(description) AS Description by disposition | rename disposition AS Disposition count AS Count | table Description Disposition Count | eval Description=if(match(Disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",Description) | sort - Count

showcase_subscriber_search0003.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0003.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_subscriber_search0003.relevance: This looks at top sourcetypes in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_subscriber_search0003.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_subscriber_search0003.name: Failed Call Metrics - Advanced
showcase_subscriber_search0003.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table _time src dst dstCountryCode Description disposition | rename _time AS Time src AS "Source #" dst AS "Destination #" disposition AS Disposition dstCountryCode AS "Destination Country"

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - Advanced
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table _time src dst dstCountryCode Description disposition | rename _time AS Time src AS "Source #" dst AS "Destination #" disposition AS Disposition dstCountryCode AS "Destination Country"

showcase_subscriber_search0004.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0004.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_subscriber_search0004.relevance: This looks at top sourcetypes in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_subscriber_search0004.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_subscriber_search0004.name: Failed Call Metrics - Geo Stats
showcase_subscriber_search0004.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName  | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - Geo Stats
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName  | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0005.id: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Failed Calls by Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.relevance: Identify where calls are failing, and which routes / gateways they are routing through.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.operationalize: This search gives us insight into where calls are failing and the path the system is routing the call through. Typically routing issues can be traced back to the underlying transit network, but with this information from our CDR logs, we can gain Operational Insight into where calls are encountering issues and proactively address these.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have the Destination/Callee, along with failure status, and the path used.

From here, we use stats to help correlate fields within the event and then format the results in a easily readable report.
showcase_subscriber_search0005.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0005.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.name: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
showcase_subscriber_search0005.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table src dst dstCountryCode partyBiD disposition Description _time | stats count values(dst) AS Destination values(disposition) AS Disposition values(Description) AS Description values(_time) as Time by partyBiD dst | rename partyBiD AS "Routed Path" | table Time Destination Description "Routed Path" count

examples.name: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: Failed Call Metrics - By Destination and Gateway
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition=FAILED OR disposition=CONGESTED | eval Description=if(match(disposition,"CONGESTED"),"Route Error",description) | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | table src dst dstCountryCode partyBiD disposition Description _time | stats count values(dst) AS Destination values(disposition) AS Disposition values(Description) AS Description values(_time) as Time by partyBiD dst | rename partyBiD AS "Routed Path" | table Time Destination Description "Routed Path" count

showcase_subscriber_search0006.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Mapping Successfully Dailed Calls
showcase_subscriber_search0006.relevance: Visual representation of where our succssfully connected calls are dialing.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.operationalize:
This search gives us insight into where our customers are calling the most in a visual representation.

From an opertational point of view, this view is a potential way to spot abnormalities in expected call behavior. And from a business persepective, we can use this information to potentially negotiate lower rates for this traffic, or perhaps raise our own prices.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee, along with succesful answer or busy status. (In this example, these two call statuses are what our metric is based on.) In addition to this, a country code is required in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the top command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0006.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0006.name: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats
showcase_subscriber_search0006.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Geo Stats
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | stats count by dstCountryName | geom geo_countries allFeatures=true featureIdfield=dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0007.id: General Call Metrics - Top Destination Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0007.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding the Top Called Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0007.relevance: Find our top dialed countries over the given time range.
showcase_subscriber_search0007.operationalize: This search gives us insight into where our customers are calling the most. From a business point of view, we can use this information to potentially negotiate lower rates for this traffic, or perhaps raise our own prices.
showcase_subscriber_search0007.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the top command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0007.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0007.name: General Call Metrics - Top Destination Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0007.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start  | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName  | top limit=10 dstCountryName

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Top Destination Countries
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Top Destination Countries
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName | top limit=10 dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0008.id: General Call Metrics - Least Called Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0008.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding the Least Called Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0008.relevance: Find our top dialed countries over the given time range.
showcase_subscriber_search0008.operationalize: This search gives us insight into where our customers are calling the most. From a business point of view, we can use this information to potentially negotiate lower rates for this traffic, or perhaps raise our own prices.
showcase_subscriber_search0008.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0008.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0008.name: General Call Metrics - Least Called Countries
showcase_subscriber_search0008.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | rare limit=10 dstCountryName

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Least Called Countries
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Least Called Countries
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | rare limit=10 dstCountryName

showcase_subscriber_search0009.id: General Call Metrics - Top Outbound Callers
showcase_subscriber_search0009.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding the Most Active Callers
showcase_subscriber_search0009.relevance: Find our top callers countries over the given time range.
showcase_subscriber_search0009.operationalize: This search gives us insight into who our top customers are and where they are calling. From a business persepective, we can use this information for targeting marketing or campaigns, along with trending over periods to look at call routing and associated costs.
showcase_subscriber_search0009.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0009.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0009.name: General Call Metrics - Top Outbound Callers
showcase_subscriber_search0009.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | top dstCountryName by src | rename src AS "Caller" dstCountryName AS "Destinaton Country" count as Count

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Top Outbound Callers
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Top Outbound Callers
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | top dstCountryName by src | rename src AS "Caller" dstCountryName AS "Destinaton Country" count as Count

showcase_subscriber_search0010.id: General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.relevance: Find our top call durations over the given time range.
showcase_subscriber_search0010.operationalize: This search gives us insight into who our top customers are and where they are calling. From a business persepective, we can use this information for targeting marketing or campaigns, along with trending over periods to look at call routing and associated costs.
showcase_subscriber_search0010.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0010.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0010.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.name: General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0010.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort - "Call Duration"

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Top Call Durations by Destination
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort - "Call Duration"

showcase_subscriber_search0011.id: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.relevance: Find our shortest call durations and their destinations. This could be used to identify fraud or abuse against the system.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where calls with the shortest duration time are going. From a business perspective, a high volume of calls like this to countries with high call tariffs might be indicative of malicious activity.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0011.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0011.dashboard: showcase_simple_search?ml_toolkit.dataset=General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.name: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0011.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort "Call Duration"

examples.name: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
examples.label: Demo Data

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Shortest Call Durations by Destination
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | lookup cdr_disposition_mapping disposition | search disposition="ANSWERED" OR disposition="BUSY" | rex field=src "(?<srcCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | rex field=dst "(?<dstCountry>\d+)(?=\d{10})" | lookup cdr_country_codes phoneCode AS dstCountry OUTPUTNEW countryName as dstCountryName ISO2 AS dstCountryCode | fields src dst dstCountryName duration | stats count list(dst) AS dst list(dstCountryName) as dstCountryName by duration src | rename duration AS "Call Duration" src AS "Caller" dst AS "Called Number" dstCountryName AS "Destination Country" | sort "Call Duration"

showcase_subscriber_search0012.description: General CDR Call Metrics - Finding Shortest Call Durations by Destination
showcase_subscriber_search0012.relevance: Find our shortest call durations and their destinations. This could be used to identify fraud or abuse against the system.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.operationalize: This search gives us insight to where calls with the shortest duration time are going. From a business perspective, a high volume of calls like this to countries with high call tariffs might be indicative of malicious activity.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.howToImplement:
For this search our data source for the CDR must have both a Source/Caller and Destination/Callee. In addition to this we need to also have a country code in order to find the dailed party. In this example, we extract a country code from the dailed number, and then use a lookup to enrich this to a country name.

From here, we can use the rare command to generate our data set and then choose a visualization, or reformat this into table.
showcase_subscriber_search0012.help: Lets look at top Splunk Sourcetypes
showcase_subscriber_search0012.name: General Call Metrics - Session Tracking
showcase_subscriber_search0012.sampleSPL: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | table _time accountcode channel src dst duration partyBiD | rex field=channel ".*-(?<sessionId>\d+$)" | search duration > 0 | convert dur2sec(duration) AS CallDuration | eval CallDuration=round((CallDuration/60),0)." minutes" | stats count values(sessionId) AS SessionID values(accountcode) AS AccountID values(dst) AS DestinationNumber values(_time) AS DialTime list(CallDuration) AS CallDuration by src dst | lookup cdr_account_mappings accountCode AS AccountID OUTPUT accountName billingState | rename src AS SourceNumber | table AccountID accountName billingState SourceNumber DestinationNumber SessionID CallDuration DialTime

visualizations.title: General Call Metrics - Session Tracking
visualizations.search: | inputlookup cdr_logs | eval _time = start | table _time accountcode channel src dst duration partyBiD | rex field=channel ".*-(?<sessionId>\d+$)" | search duration > 0 | convert dur2sec(duration) AS CallDuration | eval CallDuration=round((CallDuration/60),0)." minutes" | stats count values(sessionId) AS SessionID values(accountcode) AS AccountID values(dst) AS DestinationNumber values(_time) AS DialTime list(CallDuration) AS CallDuration by src dst | lookup cdr_account_mappings accountCode AS AccountID OUTPUT accountName billingState | rename src AS SourceNumber | table AccountID accountName billingState SourceNumber DestinationNumber SessionID CallDuration DialTime

showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.help: Lets look at Splunk Job Scheduler
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.operationalize: Words around how to operationalize things...
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.relevance: This looks at job scheduling in Splunk's internal logs....
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.description: You use splunk, but do you know Splunk?
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.name: Splunk Job Scheduler Status
showcase_Splunk_Search_Scheduler_Usage.sampleSPL: index=_internal earliest=-1y@y host=* sourcetype=scheduler (status="completed" OR status="skipped" OR status="deferred") | eval alert_actions = if(isnull(alert_actions) OR alert_actions == "", "none", alert_actions) | stats count by status | sort - count | eventstats sum(count) AS total | eval percent = round(count / total * 100, 2)." %" | fields - total | rename status as Status, app as App, user as User, savedsearch_name as "Report Name", alert_actions as "Alert Actions", count as Count, percent as "Percent of Total"

visualizations.title: Scheduler Status over all Time
visualizations.search: index=_internal earliest=-1y@y host=* sourcetype=scheduler (status="completed" OR status="skipped" OR status="deferred") | eval alert_actions = if(isnull(alert_actions) OR alert_actions == "", "none", alert_actions) | stats count by status | sort - count | eventstats sum(count) AS total | eval percent = round(count / total * 100, 2)." %" | fields - total | rename status as Status, app as App, user as User, savedsearch_name as "Report Name", alert_actions as "Alert Actions", count as Count, percent as "Percent of Total"
